awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Asymptotic Geometry and Analysis of Stochastic Partial Differential Equations
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is concerned with the development of a geometric/analytic theory of random fields, primarily those that arise from stochastic partial differential equations [SPDEs, for short]. Special emphasis is placed on certain SPDEs and related random fields that play a central role in various areas of pure and applied mathematics, mathematical oceanography, stochastic hydrology, geostatistics, and mathematical physics. The investigators will develop probabilistic, geometric, and analytic tools that will lead to a deeper understanding of a large family of physically- and mathematically-interesting SPDEs and related random fields. The investigators believe that these tools will have sufficient novelty to open new research areas, solve a number of long-standing open problems in the theory of SPDEs and related random fields, and also further promote their applicability. In addition, the activities include a sustained program to train graduate students and postdoctoral scholars, and to develop their careers in the mathematical and statistical sciences.

It is both significant and challenging to characterize the fine local and asymptotic structure of SPDEs and related random fields.  In their past investigations, the investigators have established a series of results on the asymptotic behavior, intermittency, and macroscopic-scale multifractal properties of the solutions of SPDEs and related random fields, developed potential theories for additive Levy processes and the Brownian sheet, and used them to resolve several outstanding open problems in Levy processes, the Brownian sheet, and the theory of parabolic stochastic partial differential equations. The investigators have developed ideas, based on probability theory and geometric measure theory, for the analysis of non-Markovian Gaussian and stable random fields. They have also introduced renewal-theoretic and coupling techniques for the asymptotic analysis of solutions to a large class of nonlinear SPDEs. They plan to continue their investigation of precise quantitative connections between SPDEs, random fields, potential theory, and the geometry of random fractals. They believe that further pursuit of these connections will ultimately yield novel insights into the structure of SPDEs,large-scale physical multifractals, and related random fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During the award period (August 2019-July 2023) the Proposers have established a series of significant results on analysis of stochastic partial differential equations (SPDEs) and random fields. In particular, they have obtained significant results on analytic, potential-theoretic, and geometric properties of the solutions to the stochastic heat equation, stochastic wave equation, other higher-order or fractional SPDEs, and related random fields. PI Xiao has applied the potential-theoretical and stochastic analysis tools they have developed to vector-valued and matrix-valued Gaussian random fields. 

The PIs have developed original methods for solving several outstanding open problems on SPDEs  and random fields.  The research of the Proposers has led to deeper understanding of SPDEs and random fields and will further promote their applicability in various scientific areas such as mathematical physics, geostatistics, oceanography, cosmology, and hydrology.

The discoveries of Professor Xiao have been published in more than thirty articles in peer reviewed journals and presented at national and international conferences or at seminars in universities in the U.S. and abroad. 

The past works of the Proposers demonstrate a strong commitment to the identification and career development of young talent in the mathematical sciences. Professor Xiao has integrated new discoveries in his research into student training and into courses that he taught at Michigan State University, as well as short courses that he taught in summer schools at Northwestern University (U.S.A.), the CIMPA Research School (Argentina), the South China University of Technology (China), L'Universite Lille (France), the NSF/CBMS Regional Research Conference at the University of Alabama in Huntsville (U.S.A.), and the Cadi Ayyad University (Morocco).  

During the period of this grant, Professor Xiao supervised five Ph.D. students [Dr.  Jeonghwa Lee (2019), Dr. Cheuk Yin Lee (2020), Mr. Haoxiang Feng (current), Ms. Nian Liu (current), and Mr. Dali Liu (current, co-advised by Prof. Haolei Weng and PI Xiao)]. This NSF grant provided one semester 1/2 support for Haoxiang Feng and Nian Liu, and 1/4 support for Dali Liu to conduct their dissertation research. Professor Xiao also mentored two visiting post-doctoral scholars [Dr.s R. Wang and G. Yang] and served as a member of the dissertation committees of Ms. Lara Daw (Universite de Luxembourg, Luxembourg) and Mr. Yassine Nachit (Cadi Ayyad University, Morocco).

PI Xiao helped to organize a number of activities related to the topics of their NSF-funded research. Those activities include the Special Session on "Workshop on Gaussian Processes and Related Topics" at East China Normal University in China (2019); "Seminar on Stochastic Processes" at Michigan State University (2020); and the Contributed Session "Gaussian Processes and Related Topics" at the 42nd Conferences of Stochastic Processes and Their Applications at Wuhan University in China (2022).   

Professor Xiao served as a Co-Editor in Chief of Statistics and Probability Letters, a managing editor of the Journal of Fractal Geometry, and an associate editor of the Illinois Journal of Mathematics and Science China Mathematics.
